stem: An 81-year-old client with congestive heart failure (CHF) reports seeing 'blurred greenish-yellow halos' around the television. Based on the documentation in the Cardiology Treatment & Antidote Inventory tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Visual and GI side effects on cardiac medication.
Background: Taking Digoxin 0.25mg daily for AFib/CHF. Complaining of no appetite and 'flickering' lights.
Assessment: Pulse is irregular at 48 bpm.
Recommendation: Immediate serum level check and heart rhythm monitor.

tabs.title: Cardiology Labs & Inventory
tabs.content:
TestFindingInterpretation
Serum Digoxin3.1 ng/mLCritical High (Normal 0.5-2.0)
Serum Potassium4.8 mEq/LHigh-Normal
Creatinine2.1 mg/dLDecreased clearance (Normal < 1.3)
Antidote StockDigoxin Immune Fab (DigiFab)Available in pharmacy

tabs.title: Heart Rhythm Monitor
tabs.content: Sinus Bradycardia with frequent premature ventricular contractions (PVCs).

actionOptions.text: Withhold the scheduled dose of Digoxin
Administer Digoxin Immune Fab (DigiFab) as prescribed
Place the client in a prone position to improve cardiac output
Increase Potassium intake to 8.0 mEq/L to displace the drug

parameterOptions.text: Continuous cardiac monitoring (Checking for heart block/PVCs)
Presence of a positive Kernig's sign

rationale.correct: This client has objective evidence of Acute Digoxin Toxicity (c2): Serum level 3.1 (critical), visual halos, Bradycardia (HR 48), and PVCs. The primary cause is likely renal failure (Creatinine 2.1) reducing drug clearance. Priority actions are to hold the drug (a1) and administer the antidote, DigiFab (a2). Parameter monitoring focuses on the heart rhythm (p1) (the most dangerous part of toxicity) and drug levels (p2).
clinicalPearls: If the apical pulse is < 60 in an adult, ALWAYS hold digoxin and verify.
Early signs of toxicity are often GI (Nausea/Anorexia) rather than visual.
Digoxin is primarily cleared by the kidneys; elderly patients with low GFR are at high risk.

questionTrap.trap: Asking the patient if they need new glasses for their 'halos'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Green/Yellow halos or 'flickering' lights in a heart patient is almost always Digoxin toxicity. It is a neurological/cardiac emergency, not an optometry one.

mnemonic.title: DIG-FAST
mnemonic.expansion: D-Decreased Pulse. I-Images (Halos). G-Gut (N/V). F-Feeling low (Malaise). A-Arrhythmias. S-Slow HR. T-Toxic (> 2.0).
